presentation.title: As a developer, have you ever found it difficult to...
presentation.question1: Feel legitimate in the tech world?
presentation.question4: Get motivated to keep developing your skills?

why.bigText: Let's smash the impostor syndrome together!
why.bullet1: For the developers with no engineering degree, who don't take computers to pieces every weekend and didn't start coding when they were 5
why.bullet2: Made with love by feminist, queer, inclusive devs and other fucking friendly people
why.bullet3: An open source and 100% free platform
why.bullet4: A dashing newsletter, already praised by the Tech world for its accessible and decomplexing contents

header.bigText: At Electronic Tales we want to make computer culture human readable.
header.middleText: i.e. within the reach of everyone.
header.littleText: To do so, we sat, <strike>ate toasts with slightly salted butter,</strike> we thought, we sketched out main lines (and hatched concepts).

id1.text: Building a safe space for peer support between devs

id2.text: Helping devs to strengthen their software and hardware skills

id3.text: Analysing and deciphering the geek culture codes

id4.text: Motivating devs to keep learning alongside their job

id1.text: Evening classes and workshops, online and in real

id2.text: A Slack with hundreds of friendly members

id3.text: Micro-learning, storytelling, sandbox – to learn everywhere without ZzzZ

id4.text: Cool contents in your mail box

programme.button: Okay, I want to be a part of it!

event10.title: May 31 & June 1, 2025 -- Missing Semester Micro-bootcamp
event10.subtitle:
A weekend to level up in software craftsmanship.
In Paris.
event10.description:
★ 14 hours of intensive training
★ Design patterns 🧊
★ TDD 🧪
★ Clean code 🧹
★ Hexagonal architecture and other fun stuff 🧠
★ Solidarity price of 75 euros 🫂

Find the full program and book your spot on our HelloAsso page.

event9.title: April 26 & 27, 2025 -- Algorithmia Micro-bootcamp
event9.subtitle:
A weekend to level up in algorithms.
In Paris.
event9.description:
★ 14 hours of intensive training on Big O, recursion, data structures and some famous algorithms 📷
★ 318 slides 🖌️
★ Dozens of handmade wooden arrays and linked lists (we love little strings 🪢)
★ Lots of exercises to experiment and practice 🧪
★ About one dramatic analogy every ten minutes (what, recursion doesn't make you think of a descent into hell?) 🎭
★ Solidarity price of 75 euros 🫂

Find the full program and book your spot on our HelloAsso page.

event8.title: June 8 & 9, 2024 -- Algorithmia Micro-bootcamp, 3rd session
event8.subtitle:
A weekend to level up in algorithms.
Well, since we love Paris so much, we're going back for another round.
event8.description:

★ About one dramatic analogy every ten minutes (what, recursion doesn't make you think of a descent into hell?) 🎭
★ Solidarity price of 75 euros 🫂

Find the full program and book your spot on our HelloAsso page.

event7.title: April 18 & 19, 2024 -- Algorithmia Micro-bootcamp, 2nd session
event7.subtitle:
A weekend to level up in algorithms.
And since there's more to life than Paris, we're doing a remote session to make the training as logistically accessible as possible (without falling into sleepy Zoom territory, promise).
event7.description:
★ 16 hours of intensive training on Big O, recursion, data structures and some famous algorithms 📷
★ 318 slides 🖌️

event5.title: March 3, 2024 -- Computer Archaeology Workshop at La Villette
event5.subtitle: And here we go again! Explore the components of a developer's best friend, the computer, in a warm and activist atmosphere 🤗✊
event5.description:
Another dive inside a computer 🦾

For this session, we'll have the chance to be hosted at La Villette, as part of the Villette Makerz festival ❤️

event4.title: January 21, 2024 -- Computer Archaeology Workshop!
event4.infos: 📍 1 PM - 4 PM -- La Mutinerie, 176-178 Rue Saint-Martin, 75003 Paris
event4.subtitle: Following the success of the 1st edition, we're doing it again! Explore the components of a developer's best friend, the computer, in a warm and activist atmosphere 🤗✊
event4.description:
128 DDR Radeon 9700 TX w/TV-Out… AMD A4 Micro-6400T APU… 2-Power SSD2043B 512GB…

Do these terms scare you more than the idea of a water outage on August 15th? Does your impostor syndrome reach Himalayan heights as soon as your colleagues discuss them at the coffee machine?

Then our 'Computer Archaeology' workshop is perfect for you! Hosted by Eli and Partenko, this event promises a joyful and activist exploration of the inside of a computer 🦾

For this session, we are lucky to be hosted at La Mutinerie, the most wonderful queer feminist bar in Paris ❤️🏳️‍🌈

The workshop is open to everyone, but spaces are limited. 🇫🇷 Please note that this workshop is primarily intended for a French-speaking audience, but the facilitators are fluent in English and can adapt if there are English-speaking participants 🇫🇷/🇬🇧

event3.title: December 2023 -- Successful crowdfunding campaign 💸
event3.subtitle: During autumn 2023, we ran our first major fundraising campaign to create micro-bootcamps for marginalized devs, and we exceeded 150% of the initial goal.
event3.description: Thanks to donations from 111 contributors, 3 micro-bootcamps will be created: one on algorithms, one on system design, and one on software craftsmanship. More info on our Ulule page.

event2.title: September 21, 2023 -- Get Inside Your Computer Workshop !
event2.infos: 📍 6:30 PM - 9 PM -- Ada Tech School, 116 rue du Faubourg St-Martin, Paris
event2.subtitle:
Do these terms scare you more than the idea of a water outage on August 15th? Does your impostor syndrome reach Himalayan heights as soon as your colleagues discuss them at the coffee machine?

Then our 'Computer Archaeology' workshop, organized by Electronic Tales and Ada Tech School, is perfect for you!

Put on your best Indiana Jones hat and your finest Doctor lab coat, and come dive with us into the inside of a computer 🦾

The workshop is open to everyone, but spaces are limited: sign up to secure your spot.

event1.title: Autumn 2022 - Summer 2023 -- Electronic Tales Takes a Nap
event1.subtitle: Oh my, these associations that send newsletters every 18 months...

event0.title: Autumn 2022 -- Newsletter #0
event0.subtitle: Electronic Tales is entering the newsletter game
event0.description:
This month, we're talking Hacktoberfest, a social network in Unix, and creating a mini-video game in plain JavaScript 🧋

And it's available here.

form.error500: Oops... Something went wrong on the server side. Try again or contact us.
form.waitAMinute: Wait a sec... What will happen to me if I give you my email?

id1.desc: You receive an email giving you a link to our Slack, the safe space where devs communicate in a kindly way. Also, you are subscribed to our newsletter, a dashing missive already praised by the Tech world for its contents.

id2.desc: You become a member of the Electronic Tales co-creators' pool... in other words, a member of the Team! It means that you can, if you wish so, add Electronic Tales as work experience on &Co.

id3.desc:
Fear not!

Actually, we are not going to ask you to write a series of astoundingly deep articles about z-index in CSS or to code a dark-theme for irs.gov.

You will see, it is very simple!

id4.desc: On a regular basis, but not too often, we will write you to ask you some questions of the utmost importance (e.g. which one of these designs do you prefer, which topics would interest you, etc.). Answering it will never take you more than five minutes. And if you feel a lack of inspiration, you can write us to tell us our questions are stupid (or you can just not answer at all).

id5.desc: We will owe you eternal gratitude.
id5.question: So, ready to go?

id2.name: Monday Hazard
id2.desc: Was today years old when she realized code breeding was cool.

id3.name: Le Crampon
id3.desc: If the Start-Up Nation had a face, it would be his.

id5.name: Officier Azarov
id5.desc: Technical and spiritual architect of Electronic Tales
